results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This anarchic series of comic sketches and songs expresses teenage views on school and teachers. School is seen as a meaningless prison where the students are given no space or time to explore and create.

results.title: Nightmare: the birth of horror
results.brief_description: The Victorian era saw the proliferation of the creation of horror stories that have permeated mass culture in the 21st Century. This series, written, presented and researched by Professor Christopher Frayling, recounts the origins of classic horror novels such as “Frankenstein”, “Dracula” and “The Hounds of the Baskerville”.
results.description: The Victorian era saw the proliferation of the creation of horror stories that have permeated mass culture in the 21st Century. group_works.title: Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde = Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

results.title: Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde = Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
As legend would have it, Robert Louis Stevenson would awake from a nightmare one night in 1885 inspired to write “Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde,” a tale that many critics have viewed at various times as an aberration to an otherwise successful literary career of writing adventure stories. It wasn’t the first of his nightmares though, as this informative documentary traces RLS’s childhood in Edinburgh, Scotland, which was fraught with his own medical problems, absent parents, and a very close relationship with his religious zealot Nanny. It was a time permeated by nightmares. Researched, written and presented by Professor Christopher Frayling, this episode in “Nightmare: the birth of horror” series focuses on the inspiration behind Stevenson’s tale of a divided self with a heart of darkness, its questionable sexuality, the influence of Jack the Ripper and deviance from the original work, and the impact that fans and family - in particular his wife who oversaw his authorised biography - have had on influencing the cult of Robert Louis Stevenson that is perpetuated today.

results.title: Dracula
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
Appearing on screen in over 200 different incantations, the character of Dracula is the most famous of horror icons and set the template for a mass horror movement. Taking Bram Stoker’s novel as the basis, writer and presenter Professor Christopher Frayling traces the origins of the vampire myth and the inspiration behind the novel - a combination of nightmare, literary influences, location and personal anecdotes. Frayling reviews the existing documentation of Stoker’s notes and moves through how the story came into being, the process Stoker took in writing the novel, and how it has developed, been interpreted and reinterpreted since then, in comic strips, melodramas and motion pictures.

group_siblings.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
group_siblings.creator_credit: Derek Towers and BBC-TV

results.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
Touted as being the greatest detective story every written, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s horror story is also famous for being the novel that brought the resurrection of Sherlock Holmes, and the beginning of the commercialisation of his most famous detective. Killed off in “The Final problem” in 1893, Holmes met his fate after falling into a waterfall chasing his nemesis, Moriaty - neither body was recovered. Years later, Conan Doyle became interested in folklore surrounding the legend of the Hound of the Baskervilles: Sir Hugo and his hounds of hell, punished by a fierce dog for attacking a young woman, his family fated to misfortune forever after. The only man up to the task was Holmes, and the claim was made that the Baskerville investigation was an old case rediscovered after his death. This program in “Nightmare: the birth of horror” series examines the locales, literature and country folklore that influenced Conan Doyle when writing the novel - significantly, the only one to demonstrate his interest in the natural and the supernatural world. Provides depictions of Holmes across print and screen, and what Professor Christopher Frayling believes makes the book a classic.

results.title: Frankenstein
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
In 1816 on the shores of Lake Geneva, 18 year old Mary Shelley (nee Godwin) would awake from a nightmare that provided the inspiration behind one of the classics of modern horror, “Frankenstein” or “The Modern Prometheus” - a tale of science and birthing. The origins of the nightmare were attributed to Mary’s past: the loss of her mother in childbirth, Mary’s own daughter years later, the philosophical writings of her father, new theories on the origins of life and demonstrations of galvanism. Writer, researcher and presenter Professor Christopher Frayling recounts the now legendary incident in which Mary Shelley, along with husband Percy Bysshe Shelley, Lord Byron and three others, sat around a fireside and recounted a tale of terror to horrify one another. The literary influences on Mary’s writing are outlined, as is the journey from the original novel of the birth of a beautiful creature to the fiendish monster he has since become.

results.title: Cosmopolis [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Ric Burns, Lisa Ades, New York Historical Society, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and Steeplechase Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 5: Cosmopolis (1919-1931) examines the roaring twenties, a period when New York finished assembling the components of a mass consumer society and emerged as the cultural capital of the world. In this short but dazzling period, New York became the focal point of an extraordinary array of human and cultural energies, reaching its highest levels of urban excitement and glamour. It discusses the African-American experience and the rise of new media industries. The series concludes with the skyscraper war, the stock market rise, the Crash, and- in the deafening silence that followed- the building of the Empire State Building, the greatest icon on the New York skyline. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: Sunshine and shadow
results.creator_credit: Ric Burns, Lisa Ades, New York Historical Society, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and Steeplechase Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 3: SUNSHINE AND SHADOW (1865-1898) charts New York’s history during the decades following the Civil War when it continued to grow demographically, geographically and financially at a staggering rate. It explores the incomparable fortunes of the robber barons at the unabashed corruption of political leaders in an era when the expansion of both wealth and poverty- and the schism between them- built to a complex. The episode ends with the consolidation of the five boroughs to form Greater New York on January 1, 1898. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

Episode number 5 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 5: Cosmopolis (1919-1931) examines the roaring twenties, a period when New York finished assembling the components of a mass consumer society and emerged as the cultural capital of the world. In this short but dazzling period, New York became the focal point of an extraordinary array of human and cultural energies, reaching its highest levels of urban excitement and glamour. This episode also considers the African-American experience and the rise of new media industries. The series concludes with the skyscraper war, the stock market rise, the Crash, and- in the deafening silence that followed- the building of the Empire State Building, the greatest icon on the New York skyline. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: The Country and the city [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Ric Burns, Lisa Ades, New York Historical Society, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and Steeplechase Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 1: THE COUNTRY AND THE CITY (1609-1825) charts the development of the city founded by the Dutch as a purely commercial enterprise, first as New Amsterdam, a freewheeling enclave of trade; then as the British New York a colony fuelled by slavery and a pivotal locale in the American Revolution; and ultimately as the city of New York; the nation’s capital and the place destined to define urban life in America and American ideals. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.
